I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In March 2004, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) accepted the administration of the 
Japan  Fund  for  Public  Policy  Training  (JFPPT)  as  a  new  trust  fund.  In  accordance  with 
arrangements approved by the Board of Directors, the Asian Development Bank Institute (ADBI) 
was appointed by the Government of Japan as JFPPT administrator. Following implementation of 
the JFPPT pilot project by ADBI in an initial phase, the Government of Japan held consultations 
with ADB and ADBI to make arrangements for full-scale implementation of the JFPPT program and 
its  long-term  sustainability.  Subsequently,  it  was  decided  that  the  program  could  be  more 
effectively  and  sustainably  implemented  by  ADB.  The  ADB  Board  of  Directors  approved  the 
modified implementation arrangements for the JFPPT on 14 October 2005.  
 
2.  The Fact-Finding mission was fielded in Viet Nam during 17–21 October 2005 to brief the 
Government of Viet Nam on the modified implementation arrangements, and discuss and agree 
with the Government on the objective, scope, outputs, and implementation arrangements of a 
regional technical assistance (RETA) to facilitate the transition and formulate a multiyear public 
policy training project for implementation in Viet Nam under the JFPPT program, prepare and 
conduct pilot short courses in Viet Nam, and commence preliminary work in Cambodia, and the 
Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) with the same goal and purpose (Appendix 1 gives 
the design and monitoring framework).1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Over the past few decades, developing member countries (DMCs), especially those with 
transitional economies, have been undertaking reforms aimed at promoting more market-oriented 
policies  and  preparing  themselves  for  increased  interaction  and  regional  and  international 
economic integration. One leading example of this has been Viet Nam’s transition from a centrally 
planned  economic  system  to  a  socialist-oriented  market  economy  with  associated  public 
administration  reform,  increasing  economic  integration,  and  resulting  external  competitive 
pressure. These reforms change the role of the state and the public sector and require officials in 
the central and local governments to acquire a broad range of skills in public economics to address 
new challenges and opportunities.  
 
4.  As set out in document R33-04,2 the main objective of the JFPPT is to assist DMCs and 
their  institutions  to  build  their  capacities  for  public  policy  training  and  education,  with  initial 
concentration on transition economies such as Viet Nam. The immediate purpose is to (i) conduct 
public policy training for mid-career and senior government officials and leaders at both national 
and subnational levels, who are involved in formulating and implementing public policies; and (ii) 
support initiatives to eventually establish a center of excellence for public policy education. 
 
5.  According  to  the  specific  situation  in  the  DMCs  receiving  support  from  the  JFPPT, 
assistance may be provided to enhance existing public policy training centers or to establish new 
institutions to provide education in public policy making, in addition to financing the conduct of 
carefully  designed  and  high-quality  learning  programs  in  public  policy  and  management.  To 
maximize  its  synergy  and  impact,  JFPPT-financed  programs  will  be  aligned  with  and  made

complementary to ADB’s country strategies and programs, poverty partnership agreements, and 
public administration reform programs. While the major part of the funding will come from the 
JFPPT,  cost-sharing  with  recipient  governments  and  institutions,  where  appropriate,  is  also 
envisaged. It is understood that this arrangement will enhance  the ownership and commitment of 
recipient countries and institutions and contribute to the sustainability of public policy training 
activities in the long run.  
 
6.  Recognizing  the  urgent  need  and  acknowledging  the  related  requests  to  assist  DMC 
governments in strengthening the capabilities of government officials (civil servants) in public 
policy, the JFPPT was established at ADB in 2004. ADBI undertook the preliminary work for 
implementing of the program in Viet Nam, including consultations with government agencies; 
identification  of  potential  partner  universities,  national  and  international  experts;  collection  of 
secondary information and research reports; and preparation and conduct of two demonstration 
short courses. A training program office, with modern training facilities, was established in Hanoi, to 
implement JFPPT projects in Viet Nam, and to gradually begin preparatory work in other DMCs 
such as Cambodia and the Lao PDR in later years.  
 
7.  The Government of Viet Nam (Government) believes that the discipline of public policy was 
crucial in terms of both public education and in-service training to enhance the quality of leadership 
among civil servants at all levels. Government officials, especially at middle-to-senior levels, are 
still captive to development management concepts and thinking that were more in line with the 
centralized economic planning model of the past than with Viet Nam’s free market-based growth 
aspirations. The Government believes that the transformation to the new model of economic 
development  and  social  welfare  will  be  accelerated  by  creating  a  new  generation  of  public 
managers steeped in cutting-edge knowledge and skills related to public policy, public sector 
management,  and  public  service  delivery  to  people  and  businesses.  The  Government  also 
welcomes the idea of developing the JFPPT Viet Nam program as a regional hub for public policy 
training and providing learning opportunities for other DMC officials through it. The Government 
has reconfirmed Viet Nam’s participation in the JFPPT program.3  
 
8.  Several useful lessons can be drawn from the recent experience of ADB and ADBI in 
capacity building and training projects in the DMCs. First, at the outset, design of the project and 
choice of partner institutions are fundamental to make the subsequent phases successful. Second, 
cost-sharing  arrangements  where  appropriate  and  a  participatory  approach  can  be  useful  to 
promote country ownership and effective partnership with national institutions for ensuring the 
intended project results and their sustainability. Third, “public policy” in the economic development 
field cuts across many sectors, themes, and stakeholders; sometimes it can be misconstrued as a 
sensitive area. These lessons will be duly taken into account in formulating and conducting the 
ensuing technical assistance (RETA) projects for public policy training under the JFPPT program. 
The RETA supports ADB’s thematic focus on sustainable economic growth and governance and is 
in line with the country strategy for Viet Nam, Cambodia, and Lao PDR.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The RETA is designed to formulate and implement Public Policy Training Program 2006 
under the JFPPT. The overall impact (goal) of the RETA will be an effective start-up to contribute to 
the process of enhancing the public economic policy capability of government officials in Viet Nam 
and, gradually in later years, in other DMCs such as Cambodia and Lao PDR through the JFPPT 
program. The immediate main outcome (purpose) will be to support JFPPT’s transition from its 
initial implementation to full implementation in Viet Nam; and at a later stage (i.e., from 2007) to 
begin preliminary work in Cambodia and Lao PDR (Appendix 1).  
 
10.  The RETA’s main inputs are as follows: (i) operation of the JFPPT program office in Hanoi 
for the Viet Nam program and as a regional hub4 for public policy training activities under the 
JFPPT program; (ii) formulation of a multiyear public policy training program for Viet Nam; (iii) 
commencement of preliminary work in Cambodia and Lao PDR for similar programs in the future; 
(iv) preparation and offering of pilot short courses in public economic policy analysis for mid-career 
government officials in Viet Nam; (v) a feasibility study of establishing a public policy training 
school in Viet Nam (e.g., at the Vietnam National University (VNU); (vi) training materials for short 
courses; and (vii) creation of a dedicated website for disseminating the data on the JFPPT program 
and its outputs, including training materials, key results, lessons, and a platform for distance 
learning and e-discussions. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The RETA will adopt a process approach whereby the project components will be designed  
and implemented in close consultation with the relevant government agencies and local partner 
universities such as VNU in the case of Viet Nam. The RETA will review available literature on key 
development  challenges,  and  skills  and  capabilities  required  to  address  the  new  challenges. 
Specifically, it will review recently prepared reports on training needs assessment, particularly that 
prepared for conceptualizing the trust fund (i.e., the JFPPT). With the outcome of the literature 
review and discussions with central Government ministries and agencies, the RETA team will 
identify priority subject areas for public policy training in the immediate, medium, and long term. 
 
12.  On  the  institutional  capacity-building  side,  a  detailed  review  of  VNU  in  relation  to  its 
corporate vision, plans, and resources will be carried out. The review will assist in identifying the 
potential for establishing a school of public policy, and required resources and actions. The review 
will  also  look  at  the  cost  (logistics)  sharing  possibilities,  training  of  trainers,  and  strategic 
management aspects of VNU. As to public education in public policy, a detailed survey of national 
and  regional  universities  in  Viet  Nam  will  be  undertaken,  to  help  assess  their  interests  and 
capabilities to introduce public policy-related courses at diploma and degree levels.    
  
13.  The RETA will take similar approach in the case of other DMCs such as Cambodia and Lao 
PDR for implementation of JFPPT in later years. Following the above method and activities, it will 
prepare a multi-year public policy training program for Viet Nam and start preliminary work in 
Cambodia and Lao PDR. The RETA will also prepare and conduct pilot short courses in Viet Nam 
building upon the works already carried out by the ADBI in this regard.  
                                                 
4  The RETA will synergize and complement the activities of ADB-supported regional initiatives such as Phnom Penh 
Plan for Development Management, Making Markets Work for the Poor, and Network of Public Administration 
Institutes of the Asia and Pacific Region.

4   
  
14.  The ensuing JFPPT project in Viet Nam will assist the Government at mainly two levels. On 
a broad, long-term level, it will address society’s education needs in the area of public policy. 
Currently, the discipline is not offered at any of the country’s educational institutions. There is a 
demand for the subject, especially from among those keen to make a career in government, or 
those  wishing  to  serve  in  an  international  organization,  or  institution  of  learning.  On  a  more 
immediate level, the project will provide short-term training to civil servants in the public policy field. 
A range of courses needs to be developed and offered based on the training needs assessment 
that was recently undertaken by the JFPPT program and also for the Phnom Penh Plan for 
Development Management. Civil servants at both central and provincial levels will be targeted. 
Programs for awareness, and dissemination of international and regional good practices in public 
policy will be conducted to benefit high-level government officials and leaders. In addition, an 
analytical capacity in public policy through training based on real-life case studies/projects will be 
developed at ministry and provincial levels to support immediate policy analysis and development 
requirements. 
 
15.  The RETA will assist in developing partnerships with regional and international centers of 
excellences that can best contribute to the development of the public policy discipline in Viet Nam 
and other DMCs. Research anchored in Viet Nam but with perspectives on national, regional, and 
global issues will help develop the required learning materials. Establishing a School of Public 
Policy in the country at a university like VNU that can offer degree programs in public policy, or 
shorter executive programs, will serve the overall objective of the JFPPT program. This approach 
will lead to at least five outcomes: (i) it will produce civil servants who are better qualified as 
managers and leaders of the development process, (ii) it will create a pool of indigenous lecturers 
and professors in the discipline, (iii) learning resources of an international standard will be available 
in  Viet  Nam,  (iv)  high-quality  educational  technology  (learning,  testing,  evaluating)  will  be 
developed indigenously, and (v) the School of Public Policy can develop into a center of excellence 
in the region. However, it is important that partner universities/training institutions have definite a 
long-term vision, a corporate strategy and plan on how to achieve it, and dedicated and capable 
faculties (staff) for implementing them. 
 
16.  The training modules/materials, key results, and lessons of the RETA will be disseminated 
through seminar discussions, and printed and electronic media. The RETA is envisaged to serve 
as a model for possible replication in other DMCs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing    
17.  The estimated cost of the RETA is $950,000 for 2006, which will be financed by the JFPPT. 
Voluntary  in-kind  contributions  from  the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  and  other  participating 
governments5 and universities and training institutions, will be worth about $200,000. The cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the RETA, the Viet Nam Resident Mission (VRM) will 
be responsible for overall RETA administration. Implementation will be guided by an Advisory 
Committee (AC). A highly qualified and experienced program manager will be engaged, and will be 
based in Hanoi to undertake day-to-day program management, provide leadership and oversight to 
other consultants, and assist VRM in implementing the RETA. The program manager will report to

5
the ADB Country Director, (VRM). The AC will guide and oversee JFPPT program implementation. 
Its members will comprise: senior-level representatives from central ministries, central banks, and 
partner universities such as VNU in the case of Viet Nam, and the ADB country director for Viet 
Nam, a senior-level representative from ADB Mekong Department, and a representative of the 
Government of Japan. As necessary and appropriate, AC membership will be expanded to include 
other relevant ministries and agencies, and also representatives from Cambodia and Lao PDR and 
ADB country directors in later years. The AC will draw on technical advice and inputs from the 
national and international experts, as necessary. One of the central ministries/agencies nominated 
by the Government will chair the AC and also coordinate with other government agencies for the 
Viet Nam program. Appendix 3 gives the terms of reference for the AC chair and the consultants.  
 
19.  The RETA project (for the 2006 program) will require consulting services from the following 
experts: a program manager and team leader (international, 12) program officers and economists 
(three  domestic,  12  each),  international  short-term  consultants  (20),  domestic  short-term 
consultants (30), and equivalent of domestic resource persons and interpreters (20) from partner 
universities/training  institutions/local  think-tanks  and  research  community  for  course  design, 
development,  and  delivery.  The  consultants    will  work  closely  with  the  relevant  government 
ministries/agencies and VNU to benefit from local knowledge, to determine government training 
needs and priorities, and also to provide learning opportunities to those ministries/agencies and 
VNU by involving them in designing and implementing public policy training activities. VNU will be 
given more responsibility in preparing courses and delivering them to targeted government officials 
in relation to their work experience and improvement in institutional capability.  
 
20.  ADB will engage consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. Given the nature 
and  urgency  of  RETA  mobilization,  the  consultants  will  be  engaged  on  an  individual  basis. 
Equipment and related items for website development and operations will be procured following 
ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
  
21.  The RETA will be implemented over 12 months. It will start in December 2005 and end in 
December 2006. Evaluation of implementation progress and initial outcomes of the RETA will be 
carried out through periodic reviews of the TA activities and the AC meetings. Representatives 
from the Government of Japan will be invited to participate in review missions and also in AC 
meetings. Implementation progress, including initial outcomes of the project components, will be 
delivered to all stakeholders through the biannual reports. The JRETA program manager will 
prepare and submit to ADB (i) an inception report, outlining the work plan, within 2 weeks of the 
start of the RETA; (ii) a monthly progress report; (iii) a midterm report 6 months after the RETA 
starts;  and  (iii)  a  final  report  9  months  after  the  RETA  starts,  outlining  the  work  plans  for 
subsequent years.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $950,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Japan Fund for Public Policy Training for Public Policy Training Program 2006, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

4.  Required Qualification. The consultant should have at least a postgraduate degree in 
economics or finance or business administration, excellent track record in providing leadership 
and managing technical assistance projects, and at least 10 years professional experience in 
dealing  with  governments  in  development  policy  matters  in  ADB’s  developing  member 
countries. First-hand knowledge of development policy issues in Mekong region will be an 
advantage. 
 
2.  JFPPT Program Officers/Economists (3 domestic, at 12 person-months each) 
5.  The program officers/economists will have a university degree in economics or business 
management, excellent writing and spoken English; be well-versed in development policy issues 
in Viet Nam; and have experience in undertaking applied research, including survey design, 
data processing, and econometric analysis. They will work closely with the program manager 
and designated ADB staff by providing technical assistance in coordinating and undertaking 
research activities under the JFPPT program. Their main responsibilities will include, but will not 
be limited, to the following:  
 
(i)  Assist  the  JFPPT  program  manager  in  coordinating  and  undertaking 
research and training activities under the JFPPT program. 
 
(ii)  Assist in developing the terms of reference for the research and training 
projects to be undertaken in cooperation with the JFPPT program task 
teams and the AC.   
 
(iii)  Assist  in  preparing  and  evaluating  training  proposals  submitted  by 
government ministries/agencies and the JFPPT consultants and partner 
institutions. 
 
(iv)  Assist in preparing, editing, and publishing of training materials, research 
reports, and workshop and conference proceedings (in both English and 
the local language). 
 
(v)  Assist  in  designing  and  conducting  research  and  training  workshops, 
seminars, and conferences.

Appendix 3  11 
 
 
(vi)  Assist in liaising with local and regional institutions and resource persons, 
and developing a research and training network. 
 
(vii)  Undertake/oversee the translation of research papers and policy briefs 
into Vietnamese and ensure technical accuracy.  
 
(viii)  Assist in e-dissemination and e-discussions on topics/issues related to 
the JFPPT program. 
 
(ix)  Perform any other related work assigned by ADB. 
 
3.  Short-Term Consultants (20 international, 20 person-months) 
6.  The  consultants  will  be  senior  academics/experts  and  will  have  proven  in-depth 
knowledge and training experience in the particular area under public economic policy and 
management, and preferably have familiarity with the situation of Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet 
Nam, and/or comparable developing and transitional economies. The consultants will report to 
the RETA program manager. Their responsibilities will include, but will not be limited to, the 
following: 
 
(i)  Provide intellectual leadership, including conceptual and methodological inputs 
and international good practices, to the research training projects. 
(ii)  Assist  the  partner  training  institutes/individuals  by  providing  technical  and 
intellectual inputs in refining and detailing research methodologies and related 
activities, overall research including the type of primary data to be collected 
and  their processing, curriculum development,  preparing  case  studies,  and 
training methodology.  
(iii)  Oversee the work of partner training institutes and individuals, including long 
distance supervision by e-mail, telephone/fax, or video conferencing. 
(iv)  Participate in inception, midterm, and final workshops, as necessary. 
(v)  Review work in progress and draft reports, and give recommendations for their 
improvement in overall quality and policy recommendations. 
(vi)  Assist  in  preparing  final  research  papers  and  training  materials,  including 
technical editing to improve the quality of the research reports. 
(vii)  Introduce  research  networks,  assist  in  conducting  e-discussion  on  related 
topics/issues.  
(viii)  Perform any other related work as assigned by ADB. 
 
4.  Domestic Short-Term Consultants (30 domestic, 30 person-months) 
7.  The  consultants  will  be  senior  academics/experts  from  national  universities/training 
institutions/research  centers  and  will  have  proven  in-depth  local  knowledge  and  training 
experience in the particular area under public economic policy and management. They will 
report to the JFPPT program manager. Their responsibilities will include, but will not be limited 
to, the following: 
 
(i)  Provide  local  knowledge/intellectual  inputs,  including  conceptual  and 
methodological  inputs  and  government  policies  and  priorities,  local  good 
practices, to the research and training projects/activities.

12  Appendix 3 
 
(ii)  Assist the JFPPT task teams as local partner training institutes/individuals by 
providing technical and intellectual inputs in preparing the course materials, 
case studies, and related activities, and training.  
(iii)  Assist in the feasibility study for establishing a school of public policy in Viet 
Nam. 
(iv)  Participate in inception, midterm, and final workshops, as necessary. 
(v)  Introduce  local  research  networks,  assist  in  conducting  e-discussion  on 
related topics/issues.  
(vi)  Perform any other related work as assigned by ADB. 
 
5.  Web Design and Development Consultant (1 domestic, 10 person-months) 
8.  The consultant will help in the design, development, and operation of a website for the 
JFPPT program. 
 
6.  Resource Persons (20 domestic, 20 person-months) 
9.  Resource  persons  will  be  engaged  to  help  conduct  case  studies,  prepare  training 
materials, and conduct short courses.  
 
B.  JFPPT Advisory Committee 
10.  ADB Viet Nam Resident Mission will establish a RETA advisory Committee (AC) in 
consultation with the government ministries and agencies as described in the paper, para. 18. 
The AC will meet at least twice a year.  
 
11.  The AC will review the work plan, oversee implementation, ensure coordination with 
government  agencies,  and  provide  overall  strategic  guidance  to  ensure  successful 
implementation of the JFPPT program. 
 
12.  The AC will comprise senior-level representatives from central ministries, central banks, 
and partner universities such as VNU in the case of Viet Nam; ADB country directors for Viet 
Nam,  Cambodia,  and  Lao  PDR;  and  a  representative  of  the  Government  of  Japan.  As 
necessary and appropriate, the AC membership will be expanded to include other relevant 
ministries and agencies, and also representatives from Cambodia and Lao PDR.  
 
13.  The AC will draw on technical advice and inputs from the national and international 
experts, as necessary.  
 
14.  One of the central ministries/agencies (e.g., Ministry of Planning and Investment) will 
chair the AC and also coordinate with other government agencies for the Viet Nam program.  
Specifically,  the  chair  will  (i)  coordinate/facilitate  the  consensus-building  process  through 
reviews, evaluations, and discussions within the government agencies and academic/training 
institutes regarding a public policy training program at both central and provincial levels in Viet 
Nam; (ii) ensure complementarity and synergy with ongoing and planned capacity-building and 
training programs supported by the Government and other Official Development Assistance 
(ODA)  partners;  (iii)  assist  in  aligning  the  public  policy  training  program  with  the  policy 
framework  of  the  Government’s  new  5-year  socioeconomic  development  plan,  public 
administration reform master plan, and ADB’s country strategy and program; (iv) organize any 
government clearance or approvals or visas for visiting participants, researchers and resource

Appendix 3  13 
 
persons that may be necessary for implementing the public policy training program in Viet Nam; 
and (v) undertake other JFPPT-related matters as requested by ADB, when necessary.   
 
15.  The AC will be supported by the RETA team in the administrative as well as technical 
areas as appropriate.
